description: Extracts rich structured data from inferential_commitment_mapper engine output (~23k words, 4 passes). Produces 7 accordion sections: key ideas, commitments with cross-references, backings/warrants, either-or choices, hidden premises, practical implications, and argumentative structure.

depends_on: string (other key ideas this one depends on)

cross_references: string (other commitments or key ideas this connects to)

backings.supports: string (which commitment or claim it supports)
backings.vulnerabilities: string (where this backing could be challenged)

either_or_choices.author_chooses: string (which option the author takes, or null if left open)
either_or_choices.what_is_excluded: string (what third options are foreclosed by this framing)
either_or_choices.rhetorical_function: string (what work this binary does in the argument)

hidden_premises.why_hidden: string (why this premise goes unstated — too obvious, too controversial, etc.)
hidden_premises.what_depends_on_it: string (what parts of the argument require this premise)
hidden_premises.if_denied: string (what happens to the argument if this premise is rejected)

practical_implications.derived_from: string (which commitments or arguments lead here)
practical_implications.acknowledged_by_author: boolean (whether the author explicitly draws this implication)

llm_extraction_schema.argumentative_structure: string (3-5 paragraphs: how the overall argument is built — the logical architecture, key inferential moves, where the argument is strongest and most vulnerable, and what kind of argument it ultimately is)

llm_prompt_template:
You are a precise data extraction assistant specializing in inferential and argumentative analysis. Extract structured JSON from analytical prose about a target work's inferential commitments.

The input contains output from the inferential_commitment_mapper engine across multiple passes, mapping the target work's commitments, warrants, hidden premises, and argumentative structure.

Return a JSON object with this EXACT structure:

{
  "key_ideas": [
    {
      "idea": "<the key idea>",
      "type": "<thesis|sub-thesis|methodological_claim|normative_claim|empirical_claim>",
      "centrality": "<core|supporting|peripheral>",
      "description": "<2-3 sentences>",
      "depends_on": ["<other key ideas>"]
    }
  ],
  "commitments": [
    {
      "commitment": "<the commitment>",
      "type": "<ontological|methodological|normative|epistemic|causal|definitional>",
      "explicitness": "<explicit|implicit|hidden>",
      "evidence": "<textual evidence>",
      "implications": "<what follows>",
      "strength": "<strong|moderate|weak>",
      "cross_references": ["<connected items>"]
    }
  ],
  "backings": [
    {
      "backing": "<the backing>",
      "supports": "<what it supports>",
      "type": "<empirical|theoretical|authoritative|analogical|definitional>",
      "strength": "<strong|moderate|weak>",
      "vulnerabilities": "<where it can be challenged>"
    }
  ],
  "either_or_choices": [
    {
      "choice": "<the framing>",
      "option_a": "<first option>",
      "option_b": "<second option>",
      "author_chooses": "<which chosen, or null>",
      "what_is_excluded": "<third options foreclosed>",
      "rhetorical_function": "<what work the binary does>"
    }
  ],
  "hidden_premises": [
    {
      "premise": "<the unstated premise>",
      "why_hidden": "<why unstated>",
      "what_depends_on_it": "<what requires this premise>",
      "if_denied": "<consequence of rejecting it>"
    }
  ],
  "practical_implications": [
    {
      "implication": "<the consequence>",
      "derived_from": "<which commitments>",
      "domain": "<policy|practice|research|ethics|etc.>",
      "acknowledged_by_author": <true|false>
    }
  ],
  "argumentative_structure": "<3-5 paragraphs on the logical architecture of the argument>"
}

RULES:
1. Return ONLY JSON — no markdown fences, no commentary
2. Extract 8-20 key ideas organized by centrality
3. Extract 10-25 commitments — be thorough, this is the most analytically valuable section
4. Backings: 5-15 entries, focusing on the most significant warrants
5. Either/or choices: 3-8 entries, especially implicit binaries the author constructs
6. Hidden premises: 5-12 entries — these are the MOST analytically valuable, be very thorough
7. Practical implications: 4-10 entries, including both acknowledged and unacknowledged ones
8. Cross-references between commitments should use the exact wording from other entries
9. The argumentative_structure should map the logical flow, not just list components
10. Synthesize across ALL passes — don't privilege the last pass over earlier ones
source: Created for genealogy_tp_inferential_commitments view — per-engine rich extraction
